section.name: Website Development
section.p: After having set up your ECM, you may very well want to publish the contents of the repository by means of a website. This means that your website has to connect to the repository. As the repository is Java Content Repository (JCR) compliant, Java clients using this standard can communicate with the repository, see JCR Interface. Besides that, Hippo has developed a library on top of the JCR layer that is called the Hippo Site Toolkit, which is targeted at JSP clients, for easy website development.

subsection.name: Using Hippo Site Toolkit
subsection.p: For the purpose of fast site development, Hippo has developed the Hippo Site Toolkit, or the HST for short, targeted at JSP frontends. It features:

ul.li: An expression language to retrieve repository content, using JSP 2.0's standard JSTL Expression Language (see here). On how to use it, see here.
A servlet for serving binaries like images, see here.
The possibility to use URL mapping, i.e. use the URL to locate content and subsequently find it's view page, see here.
A jsp tag library for higher level repository access functionality, see here.

subsection.p: See including the HST on how to include the HST in your application.
See HST configuration on how to set up and configure the HST.
See configuration example for an example web.xml.

subsection.name: Running the sample HST site
subsection.p: The show the possiblities of the HST in practice, a complete JSP site has been made available for download. It is in fact the currently running onehippo.com website. To run it, you also need a combined CMS 7 / Repository 2 with initial content in it.
On how to run the example site, see here.
